metadata.title: Motorcycle Loan Amortization Calculator (Monthly, True Bi‑Weekly, Accelerated Bi‑Weekly)
metadata.description: Calculate payment amounts, number of payments, total paid and interest for motorcycle loans with support for monthly, true bi‑weekly (26 payments/year) and accelerated bi‑weekly (half‑monthly payments every two weeks) methods. Includes clear assumptions and accuracy caveats referencing standards.

monthly.label: Standard Monthly Amortization
monthly.description: Classic amortizing loan with one payment per month.

payment.expression: principal * (r * pow(1 + r, n)) / (pow(1 + r, n) - 1)
payment.label: Monthly payment (principal + interest)

biweekly_true.label: True Bi‑Weekly (26 payments/year)
biweekly_true.description: Payment every two weeks with 26 equal payments per year (periodic rate = APR/26).

payment.expression: principal * (r * pow(1 + r, n)) / (pow(1 + r, n) - 1)
payment.label: Bi‑weekly payment (principal + interest)

biweekly_accelerated.label: Accelerated Bi‑Weekly (half monthly every two weeks)
biweekly_accelerated.description: Pays half the standard monthly payment every two weeks. This typically results in an extra month of payments per year and faster payoff. Calculation derives the half‑monthly payment from the standard monthly schedule and then computes required bi‑weekly periods under the bi‑weekly periodic rate.

monthly_payment.expression: principal * (monthly_rate * pow(1 + monthly_rate, monthly_n)) / (pow(1 + monthly_rate, monthly_n) - 1)
monthly_payment.label: Derived standard monthly payment

payment.label: Accelerated bi‑weekly payment (half monthly every two weeks)

n.label: Estimated number of bi‑weekly payments to amortize at the accelerated payment amount

introduction: This calculator estimates payments and amortization outcomes for motorcycle loans using three modes: standard monthly, true bi‑weekly (26 equal payments per year) and accelerated bi‑weekly (half of the monthly payment every two weeks). Use it to compare payment amounts, estimated total paid and estimated interest for different schedules.

Results are computed from standard amortization formulas. For accelerated bi‑weekly, the tool derives a half‑monthly payment then computes the equivalent number of bi‑weekly periods at the bi‑weekly periodic rate; this is a common method used to show the typical faster payoff from making half‑monthly payments every two weeks.
methodology: Calculations use standard amortizing loan mathematics: periodic interest rate = APR / periods per year; payment is computed from the annuity formula: payment = P * (r*(1+r)^n)/((1+r)^n - 1). Number of periods and total paid are derived from the chosen payment frequency.

Where analytic inversion is required (accelerated bi‑weekly number of periods), the logarithmic inversion of the amortization equation is used. The tool treats any user 'extra payment per period' as an additional fixed amount applied each scheduled payment period and multiplies it into the simple projections; iterative recalculation of the amortization schedule with changing principal is not performed in this projection mode and may differ slightly from a full period-by-period amortization.
how_is_calculated: Number of periods n = term_years * payments_per_year.

For accelerated bi‑weekly: monthly payment is computed first; accelerated payment = monthly payment / 2; then n is solved via n = log(payment / (payment - r * principal)) / log(1 + r) using the bi‑weekly periodic rate r = APR/100/26.
Total paid (approximate) = (scheduled payment + extra per period) * n; total interest = total paid - principal.

faqs.question: What is the difference between true bi‑weekly and accelerated bi‑weekly?
faqs.answer: True bi‑weekly means 26 equal payments per year with the periodic rate set to APR/26. Accelerated bi‑weekly typically uses half the monthly payment paid every two weeks; because there are 26 two‑week periods, this results in an extra half‑monthly payment annually and usually a faster payoff.

faqs.question: Are extra payments handled exactly?
faqs.answer: This tool treats an extra payment per scheduled period as a constant add‑on and multiplies it by the estimated number of periods to produce an approximate total paid and total interest. A precise, period‑by‑period amortization with changing principal requires an iterative schedule and is available in detailed amortization tools.

faqs.question: How accurate are the numbers?
faqs.answer: Numbers use standard mathematical formulas. For high precision or for legally binding payoff figures, request an amortization schedule or payoff statement from your lender. See the accuracy and security notes in citations.

faqs.question: Is APR the same as the interest rate I enter?
faqs.answer: This calculator expects an annual percentage rate (APR) as a simple nominal annual interest rate without additional lender fees. If your lender includes fees rolled into the loan, the effective APR may differ.

faqs.question: How should I use the results to compare loan offers?
faqs.answer: Compare on the same payment frequency and include any lender fees in the principal if those fees are financed. Use the total interest and payoff time to compare cost and term differences.

glossary.definition: Repaying loan principal and interest over time in scheduled payments so that the loan balance reaches zero at term end.
Annual Percentage Rate; the nominal annual interest rate used to compute periodic interest here. Does not automatically include all lender fees unless those fees are added to the financed principal.
26 equal payments per year with periodic rate calculated as APR/26.
A schedule where half of the monthly payment is paid every two weeks, resulting in 26 payments per year and typically faster payoff.
The APR divided by the number of payment periods per year (for example APR/12 for monthly, APR/26 for bi‑weekly).
